Apple's new FaceTime feature stops faces from bouncing around in video calls — here's how to use it ... . This is still on by default, but Apple added an option to turn it off in iOS 13.5 and iPadOS 13.5, which were released earlier this month. If you turn it off, FaceTime will act a bit more like Zoom and other video chat software, without boxes that resize all of the time. Here's how to use it: Make sure you're running the latest iPad and iPhone software by going to Settings > General > Software Update. You should be on iOS 13.5, and you will see an option to update your software if you're on an earlier version. Open Settings. Choose FaceTime. Scroll down the page and turn off the toggle next to "Speaking" under the section called "Automatic Prominence." Chatting with two of my colleagues. Todd Haselton | CNBC Now, during group ...
